explainGeneralMuseum.m_param: Turin was the first Italian city to promote a public modern art collection as an integral part of its Civic Museum, opened back in 1863. In 1895, the modern art collection, with all its paintings, statues and drawings, was moved into a wing designed by architect Giuseppe Calderini for the Fourth National Exposition

The building that was standing in this very area was destroyed in 1942 during Anglo-American bombardments. The majority of the art works had been secured by the director Vittorio Viale, who worked hard for the reconstruction of the new museum site.
The project was entrusted to Carlo Bassi and Goffredo Boschetti, two young architects from Ferrara who proposed a truly innovative solution for the time.

The 31st of October 1959 the new site for the Civic gallery for modern and contemporary art, or GAM, where all the collections are hosted to this very day, was inaugurated. Since 2003, GAM have been part of Fondazione Torino Musei and its collection consists of approximately 45000 art works dating from the 18 hundreds to the present days.
If you would you like to start the tour, please say: let's start the tour. If you have more questions, please say: list of questions.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: Daphne, shown here in a very relaxed and contemplative pose, was pregnant. Their son, Francesco Casorati, was born in 1934 and he too became an artist of international fame.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Felice Casorati was born in Novara in 1883. In 1907 he exhibits the painting entitled Portrait of a Lady at the Venice Biennale. He is inspired by the paintings of Cezanne and Piero della Francesca. He opens his studio in Turin and becomes the protagonist and promoter of the cultural and artistic life of the city.

He meets Riccardo Gualino who commissions him his own portrait and that of his family and entrusts him with the project for the private theater of his home. Casorati will be present at all major exhibitions in Italy and abroad and there will be many awards on the occasion of the many monographic exhibitions.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: In Turin the Thirties brought great changes in the artistic panorama. Casorati founded the school in via Mazzini in which he promotes young emerging artists including some abstract painters such as Osvaldo Licini, who we will find in the next stage.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: On my left we can see the painting by Felice Casorati entitled Daphne at Pavarolo.

The artist paints his wife Daphne, the canvas is from 1934. This large composition presents an articulated perspective game: the background of the landscape, beyond the shoulders of Daphne, sitting on the windowsill, is reflected on the mirrored glass of the window shutters thus giving a sense of panoramic vision.

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: Let's go to the first work in the next room. The collection of modern art by the city of Turin began with the founding of the Civic Museum in 1863, the first city in Italy to promote a public collection of modern art. This collection was with the collections of Ancient Art in a building at the Mole Antonelliana.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: The work is made with an enamel paint applied to a wooden board. The peculiarity lies in the frame, whose lower edge is mounted as if to free the geometric figure contained within it. For the artist, painting is the art of colors and signs, in which the signs express strength and will, while colors represent the magical aspect of the work.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Osvaldo Licini was born in 1894 in Monte Vidon Corrado, in the Marche region. He studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Bologna. He moved to Paris and there his works hit the public and critics right away. Only in the Thirties did the abstract art season begin. He joins the group of the Galleria Il Milione, which also includes Soldati, Veronesi, Fontana, and Melotti.

He participates in the first collective exhibition of Italian abstract art of 1935, in the Casorati studio in Turin. artist immerses himself in his imaginary world. Famous are his Rebel Angels and his Amalasunte.

In 1925 he went back to live in his hometown where he stayed until his death in 1958. In 2008 the pianist and author Giovanni Allevi, also from the Marche region, dedicated a composition to Osvaldo Licini entitled Angelo Ribelle.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: Already in 1968 the Civic Gallery of Modern Art of Turin had created a large anthological exhibition dedicated to the painting of Osvaldo Licini. That exhibition consecrated the artist to a not indifferent role in the museum policy of the Gallery which had already bought two works for the collection in view of the future exhibition in 1957: La sera (grande) of 1950 and The winter of 1951.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: On my right we can see the work by Osvaldo Licini entitled Bird 2.
For Osvaldo Licini, geometry takes on a poetic value very different from that practiced by his fellow Milanese abstractionists and his other contemporaries.

For him, painting, unlike architecture, is still an irrational art made up of fantasy and imagination, of freely conceived colors and shapes that he builds and disassembles in a universe of elementary geometries. Here the image of a bird is resolved by painting a dynamic triangular wing that breaks the rules of the perimeter of the picture.
pointToRightBothArms
idleMove
Do you have any questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: Let's go to the second work. From 1895 to 1942 The modern art collection was exhibited in a pavilion in Corso Siccardi (now Corso Galileo Ferraris), which was destroyed during the Anglo-American bombings during World War II.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: The couple of lovers that appears on the left side of the canvas are Marc Chagall and his wife Bella. The artist also paints himself in the face positioned at the bottom right, to create a second head of the rooster, and writes his name not just in the signature, but also on the sign of the house depicted in the foreground.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Son of Russian Jews, he studied in Petersburg and in 1910 he moved to Paris, where he met several avant-garde intellectuals. In 1914 he returned to Russia via Berlin, where he held his first personal exhibition. He emigrated to the United States where he lived between 1941 and 1947 and then moved to the Mid√¨ of France.

In addition to painting, immediately recognizable for its dreamlike subjects and bright colors, he engages in scenography, stained glass, decoration and frescoes. He dies at 97 in Saint-Paul-de-Vence, where he lived.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: The work was purchased at the 1948 Venice Biennale by the director of the GAM Vittorio Viale. It was the first purchase of a foreign work, made when the current GAM did not yet exist, given that the previous site had been bombed in 1942.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: On my right we can see the painting by Marc Chagall entitled in my village.

The work represents the artist's birthplace, in present-day Belarus. The Russian element evoked in this intense painting is poetically present in the fantastic solution of the landscape. The place, the dear and familiar one of childhood spent in Vitebsk, is told through memory and imagination.

Old wooden dachas, narrow streets in the snow, young lovers, pets, united in a fantastic world of idyllic quiet. The ringing sumptuousness of the blue color, with the dense white light of the moon placed in the center of the canvas, give the canvas a sense of magic, of dream but also of melancholy.
pointToRightBothArms

Do you have any questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: Let's go to the third work. In Corso Galileo, the construction of the building designed by Carlo Bassi and Goffredo Boschetti began and the building was inaugurated in 1959. The modern art collection was moved to the two floors of the new building, at the behest of director Vittorio Viale.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: Alberto Burri graduated in medicine. During the Second World War he was interned in a prison camp in Texas until 1946. After that experience he began to develop these absolutely novel works in the Italian and international art scene that represent his vision of informal art.

While for some critics these works represent dramatic memories of the second post-war period, Burri makes it clear that his research aims to create works that are free and devoid of historical or social references. The work is therefore appreciable as a compositional study of assembled materials and different surfaces
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Burri graduated in medicine in 1940 and began to devote himself to painting during the war, while he was a prisoner in Texas. Returning to Rome in 1946, he devoted himself exclusively to painting, adopting a non-figurative language and progressively accentuating the material aspect of his research in the series of Blacks, Tars and Molds.

In 1951 he founded the Origine Group and began the Sacchi series, collections of jute bags reassembled on the frame with cuts, seams and writings that document the history of their previous use. At the end of the 1950s Burri used the flame to cut, weld and compose the Combustion and the Irons, one of which is present in this room. Burri died in Nice in 1995.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: Sacco is a work from 1952. In the same year a solo exhibition of his entitled "Neri e Muffe" was held in Rome, while at the Venice Biennale one of the first works made with sacks was rejected by the jury.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: Both on my right and on my left there are works by the artist Alberto Burri, born in citt√† di Castello in the province of Perugia.

The work on my right is titled Sacco, and it was created in 1952. Burri's choice of materials immediately translates into a choice of shape, as the artist does not give up to lay out the jute bags on the loom, but intervenes with cuts and sutures in order to fix the image of the worn material, according to a precise spatial organization.

In this work, the diversified textures of the different types of jute interact with each other and with the fragments of painted canvas, in a tessellation of grains, shapes and colors that highlight the desire to bring recycled materials back to the language of painting.

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: Let's go to the fourth opera. In the 1980s, this building was declared uninhabitable and reopened after a long series of restorations in July 1993. In 2009 the collection was reorganized, no longer following the chronological succession of the works on display but rather a logical plot of View, Genre, Childhood and Specularity.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: After his death, the fame and value of Warhol's works grew to the point of making him the second most bought and sold artist in the world after Pablo Picasso. This screen printing is the museum's highest-rated work.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Warhol was born in 1928 in Pittsburgh and in fifty-two he moved to New York where he worked as a designer in advertising. In the 1960s he began to paint subjects drawn from the metropolitan landscape with increasingly impersonal and homogeneous chromatic layers.

These subjects, cans of soup, boxes of detergents, Coca-Cola bottles, are represented as they are seen on supermarket shelves, lined up and repeated serially on the canvas. In the sixty-three he abandons painting to move on to mechanical reproduction of images through screen printing.

Alongside consumer products, as if to place them on the same level, he represents the most famous personalities of his period including Marilyn Monroe and Elvis Presley or, as in this case, road accidents or other images taken from the front pages of newspapers. Warhol dies in New York at only 59 years old.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: Often the vocabulary of Pop Art consists in the choice by the artists to seek inspiration among the images of the repertoire of mass communication that become bursting between the end of the 50s and the beginning of the 60s.

To underline the process of emptying of meaning to which the icons of contemporary life are destined, taking it to extremes with the system of repetition. In this work he also uses an orange color that underlines the artificial and inauthentic character of the representation.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: We have arrived. On my left there is a screen print by Andy Warhol made in 1963.

This screenprint was created by the famous Philadelphia artist, Andy Warhol and represents a car accident in which the victims are young boys.The scene is taken from a photograph printed on the front page of a newspaper and is repeated 11 times.

Warhol leaves a space at the bottom right of the screen printing as if to communicate that the repetition could be infinite. The repetition of the image is typical of POP ART and emphasizes the contrast between the drama of the event, in this case a road accident, and the loss of meaning implicit in the serial iteration that transforms it into a show.

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: Let's go to the fifth work. Following the new reorganization in 2013, on the occasion of the 150th anniversary of the GAM collections, the Infinito, Speed, Ethics and Nature paths were created.
The gallery's heritage consists of over 47,000 works including paintings, sculptures, installations and videos. In the basement there are also important exhibitions as well as a rich video library.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: Che fare is a 1968 work, made with natural and artificial materials. The theme of reusability is a principle that governs Merz's works both from a formal and a conceptual point of view. For Merz, reality is subject to constant dynamism, things continue to exist in other forms even after they apparently disappear.

In the same way the works do not end at the time of their realization but continue to exist and to transform over time. This is why many materials come from the natural world, such as in this work in which wax is present which, with the warmth of neon, is constantly transformed.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to finish the tour.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Merz was born in Milan in 1925 but grew up and worked in Turin. Here he met critic Germano Celant, who coined the term ‚ÄúArte Povera‚Äù and included him among the exponents of this new language.

He has participated in the group's first exhibitions since sixty-seven, experimenting with the combination of natural substances, branches, leaves, stones, wax, glass, with the artificial element of neon. With the adoption of the shape of the igloo, around 1968, the definitive departure from the two-dimensional plane of the wall takes place.

In the same year he begins to insert in his works the Fibonacci mathematical logic series, 1,1,2,3,5,8, this progression according to Merz expresses the increasing intensity of psychic and physical energy that must characterize every artistic operation.
Since the late seventies he went back to figurative art and created large animals with archaic, prehistoric forms, as defined by the artist. Mario Merz died in Turin in November 2003.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to finish the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: Mario Merz is one of the leading names in the artistic movement defined in 1967 by the critic Germano Celant, Atre Povera. The cinema, the theater, the visual arts become, for the artists who adhere to this current of thought, the means to record just reality and the present.

They eliminate from their research all that may seem mimetic reflection and representation, to arrive at a type of art that is, precisely defined, Povera or poor. And the materials used are also poor, anti-artistic such as rags, papier-m√¢ch√©, neon tubes but also vegetable, animal and mineral materials for their inherent expressive characteristics.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to finish the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: We have arrived. On my left, on the floor, we can find the work of one of the greatest exponents of poor art: Mario Merz.
Merz grows and works in Turin. In the mid-sixties he begins to abandon painting to experiment with the use of different materials, such as neon tubes, wax and everyday objects.

In this work, a simple iron saucepan is filled with wax and from the wax emerges an inscription made with a fluorescent neon tube that poses a fundamental question that can be connected both to the world of art and to be considered in an existential sense: what to do?

explainGeneralProject.m_param: Questa dimostrazione fa parte del progetto 5G Tours, finanziato dalla comunit√† europea. Questo progetto si prefigge di studiare le applicazioni del 5G in differenti campi tra cui la robotica, prendendo, nello specifico, come caso d'uso l'impiego di un robot quale guida all'interno di un museo.

explainGeneralMuseum.m_param: Torino fu la prima citt√† italiana che promosse una raccolta pubblica di arte moderna come parte integrante del proprio Museo Civico, aperto nel 1863. Nel 1895 la collezione d'arte moderna, quadri, statue, disegni, fu trasferita in un padiglione progettato per la Quarta Esposizione Nazionale dall'architetto Giuseppe Calderini.

Il palazzo che sorgeva nella stessa area odierna fu distrutto nel 1942 durante i bombardamenti angloamericani. La maggior parte delle opere erano state messe al sicuro dall'allora direttore Vittorio Viale che si adoper√≤ per la ricostruzione della nuova sede museale.
Il progetto fu affidato ai giovani architetti ferraresi Carlo Bassi e Goffredo Boschetti, che realizzarono una proposta molto innovativa per il periodo.

Il 31 ottobre del 1959 venne inaugurata la nuova sede della Galleria Civica d' Arte Moderna e Contemporanea dove ancora oggi sono ospitate le raccolte. Dal 2003 la GAM fa parte della Fondazione Torino Musei e la sua collezione √® formata all'incirca di da 45.000 opere dall' Ottocento ai giorni nostri.
Ora, se volete proseguire chiedetemi di iniziare il tour, altrimenti chiedetemi la lista di domande.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Felice Casorati nasce a Novara nel 1883. Nel 1907 espone alla Biennale di Venezia il quadro intitolato Ritratto di signora. Conosce Riccardo Gualino che gli commissiona il proprio ritratto e quello dei familiari e lo incarica del progetto per il teatro privato della sua abitazione. Casorati sar√† presente a tutte le principali manifestazioni espositive in Italia e all'estero, e ricever√† molti riconoscimenti in occasione delle tante mostre monografiche.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Osvaldo Licini √® nato nel 1894 a Monte Vidon Corrado, nelle Marche. Studia all'Accademia di Belle Arti di Bologna. Si trasferisce a Parigi e l√¨ le sue opere colpiscono pubblico e critica fin da subito. Solo negli anni Trenta inizia la stagione dell'astrattismo. Entra nel gruppo della Galleria Il Milione, di cui fanno parte anche Soldati, Veronesi, Fontana, e Melotti.

Partecipa alla Prima mostra collettiva di arte astratta italiana del '35, nello studio di Casorati a Torino.A PARTIRE DAGLI ANNI 50, l'artista si immerge nel suo mondo immaginario. Famosi sono i suoi Angeli Ribelli e le sue Amalasunte.

Dal 1925 ritorna a vivere nel paese natale dove risiede fino alla morte, nel 1958. Nel 2008 il pianista e autore Giovanni Allevi, anch'esso marchigiano, dedica ad Osvaldo Licini una composizione intitolandola Angelo Ribelle.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: Alberto Burri si √® laureato in medicina.  Durante la seconda guerra mondiale viene internato in un campo di prigionia in Texas fino al 1946. Dopo quell'esperienza inizia ad elaborare queste opere assolutamente inedite nel panorama artistico italiano ed internazionale che  rappresentano la sua visione dell'arte informale.

Mentre per alcuni critici queste opere rappresentano drammatici ricordi del secondo periodo post bellico, Burri chiarisce che le sue ricerche mirano a creare opere libere e prive di riferimenti storici o sociali. L'opera √® quindi apprezzabile come studio compositivo di materiali assemblati e di diverse superfici.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Burri si laurea in Medicina nel 1940 e inizia a dedicarsi alla pittura durante la guerra, mentre si trova prigioniero in Texas. Rientrato a Roma, nel 1946, si dedica esclusivamente alla pittura, adottando un linguaggio non figurativo ed accentuando progressivamente l'aspetto materico della sua ricerca nella serie dei Neri, dei Catrami e delle Muffe.

Nel 1951 fonda il Gruppo Origine e inizia la serie dei Sacchi, assemblaggi di sacchi di iuta ricomposti sul telaio con tagli, cuciture e scritte che  documentano la storia del loro uso precedente. Alla fine degli anni Cinquanta Burri utilizza la fiamma per tagliare, saldare e comporre le Combustioni e i Ferri di cui uno √® presente in questa sala. Burri muore a Nizza nel 1995.

explainOpera.m_param: Sia alla mia destra sia alla mia sinistra sono presenti opere dell'artista Alberto Burri, nato a citt√† di Castello in provincia di Perugia.

L'opera alla mia destra si intitola Sacco, ed √® stata realizzata nel 1952. La scelta materica di Burri si traduce immediatamente in scelta di forma, in quanto l'artista  non rinuncia ad impaginare i sacchi di iuta sul telaio, ma interviene con tagli e suture in modo da fissare, secondo un'organizzazione spaziale precisa, l'immagine della materia consunta.

In quest'opera le trame diversificate dei differenti tipi di iuta dialogano tra loro e con i frammenti di tela dipinta, in una tassellatura di grane, forme e colori che evidenziano la volont√† di ricondurre al linguaggio della pittura i materiali di recupero.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: Dopo la morte, la fama e la quotazione delle opere di Warhol, sono cresciute al punto da renderlo il secondo artista pi√π comprato e venduto al mondo dopo Pablo Picasso. Questa serigrafia √® l'opera pi√π quotata del museo.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Warhol nasce nel 1928 a Pittsburgh e nel cinquantadue si trasferisce a New York dove lavora come disegnatore pubblicitario. Nel Sessanta inizia a dipingere soggetti tratti dal paesaggio metropolitano con stesure cromatiche sempre pi√π impersonali e omogenee.

Questi soggetti, barattoli di minestra, scatole di detersivi, bottiglie di Coca-Cola, vengono rappresentate come si vedono negli scaffali dei supermercati, allineate e ripetute serialmente sulla tela.
Nel sessantatr√© abbandona la pittura per passare alla riproduzione meccanica delle immagini attraverso la serigrafia.

Accanto ai prodotti di consumo, come a porli sullo stesso livello, rappresenta i personaggi pi√π famosi del suo periodo tra cui Marilyn Monroe ed  Elvis Presley, oppure, come in questo caso, incidenti stradali o altre immagini tratte dalle prime pagine dei quotidiani. Warhol muore a New York a soli 59 anni.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: Spesso il vocabolario della Pop Art consiste nella scelta da parte degli artisti di cercare ispirazione tra le immagini di repertorio della comunicazione di massa che divengono prorompenti tra la fine degli anni '50 e l'inizio degli anni '60.

Warhol tende a sottolineare il processo di svuotamento di significato cui le icone della vita contemporanea sono destinate, portandolo agli estremi con il sistema della ripetizione.In questa opera utilizza inoltre un colore arancione che sottolinea il carattere artificiale e inautentico della rappresentazione.

explainOpera.m_param: Siamo arrivati. Alla mia sinistra c'√® una serigrafia del famosissimo artista di Philadelphia Andy Warhol, realizzata nel 1963.

Questa serigrafia rappresenta un incidente stradale in cui le vittime sono dei giovani ragazzi.La scena √® tratta da una fotografia stampata in prima pagina di un quotidiano e viene ripetuta 11 volte.

Warhol lascia uno spazio in basso a destra della serigrafia come a voler comunicare che la reiterazione potrebbe essere infinita. La ripetizione dell'immagine √® tipica della POP ART e  sottolinea il contrasto tra la drammaticit√† dell'evento, in questo caso un incidente stradale, e la perdita di significato implicita nell'iterazione seriale che lo trasforma in spettacolo.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: Che fare √® un'opera del 1968, realizzata con materiali naturali e artificiali. Il tema del riutilizzo √® un principio che governa le opere di Merz sia da un punto di vista formale, che concettuale.

Per Merz la realt√† √® soggetta ad un dinamismo costante, le cose continuano ad esistere sotto altre forme anche quando all'apparenza sono scomparse. Allo stesso modo le opere non si concludono al momento della loro realizzazione ma continuano ad esistere e a trasformarsi nel tempo.
Ecco perch√© molti materiali provengono dal mondo naturale, come in quest'opera in cui √® presente la cera che, con il calore del neon, si trasforma costantemente.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Merz nasce a Milano nel 1925 ma cresce e lavora a Torino. Qui incontra il critico Germano Celant, che conia il termine ‚ÄúArte Povera‚Äù e lo include tra gli esponenti di questo nuovo linguaggio.

Partecipa fin dal sessantasette alle prime mostre del gruppo sperimentando l'accostamento di sostanze naturali, rami, foglie, pietre, cera, vetro, all'elemento artificiale del neon. Con l'adozione della forma dell'igloo, intorno al 1968, avviene l'allontanamento  definitivo dal piano bidimensionale della parete.

Nello stesso anno inizia ad inserire nelle sue opere la serie logico matematica di Fibonacci, 1,1,2,3,5,8, questa progressione esprime secondo Merz il crescere di intensit√† dell'energia psichica e fisica che deve caratterizzare ogni operazione artistica.
Dalla fine degli anni settanta recupera la figurazione realizzando grandi animali con forme arcaiche, preistorici, come li definisce l'artista.Mario Merz muore a Torino nel novembre del 2003.
Avete altre domande? Se non sapete cosa chiedere, chiedetemi la lista delle domande. Se non avete domande ditemi, fine del tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: Mario Merz rientra tra i nomi di spicco del movimento artistico definito nel 1967 dal critico Germano Celant, Atre Povera. Il cinema, il teatro, le arti visive diventano per gli artisti che aderiscono a questo pensiero dei mezzi per registrare unicamente la realt√† e il presente.

Essi eliminano dalla loro ricerca tutto ci√≤ che pu√≤ sembrare riflessione e rappresentazione mimetica, per approdare ad un tipo di arte che viene appunto definita, Povera. E poveri sono anche i materiali utilizzati, anti-artistici come ad esempio gli stracci, la cartapesta, i tubi al neon ma anche materiali vegetali, animali e minerali per le loro insite caratteristiche espressive.
Avete altre domande? Se non sapete cosa chiedere, chiedetemi la lista delle domande. Se non avete domande, fine del tour.

explainOpera.m_param: Siamo arrivati. Alla mia sinistra, sul pavimento, troviamo l'opera di uno dei massimi esponenti dell'arte povera: Mario Merz.
Merz cresce e lavora a Torino. A met√† degli anni sessanta inizia ad abbandonare la pittura per sperimentare l'uso di materiali diversi, come i tubi al neon, la cera, e gli oggetti d'uso quotidiano.

In quest'opera una semplice casseruola in ferro √® riempita di cera, e da questa emerge un'iscrizione composta con un tubo fluorescente al neon, che ci pone una domanda fondamentale, collegabile sia al mondo dell'arte, sia ad essere considerata in senso esistenziale. Che fare?

explainGeneralMuseum.m_param: Turin was the first Italian city to promote a public modern art collection as an integral part of its Civic Museum, opened back in 1863. In 1895, the modern art collection, with all its paintings, statues and drawings, was moved into a wing designed by architect Giuseppe Calderini for the Fourth National Exposition

The building that was standing in this very area was destroyed in 1942 during Anglo-American bombardments. The majority of the art works had been secured by the director Vittorio Viale, who worked hard for the reconstruction of the new museum site.
The project was entrusted to Carlo Bassi and Goffredo Boschetti, two young architects from Ferrara who proposed a truly innovative solution for the time.

The 31st of October 1959 the new site for the Civic gallery for modern and contemporary art, or GAM, where all the collections are hosted to this very day, was inaugurated. Since 2003, GAM have been part of Fondazione Torino Musei and its collection consists of approximately 45000 art works dating from the 18 hundreds to the present days.
If you would you like to start the tour, please say: let's start the tour. If you have more questions, please say: list of questions.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Felice Casorati was born in Novara in 1883. In 1907 he exhibits the painting entitled Portrait of a Lady at the Venice Biennale. explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Merz was born in Milan in 1925 but grew up and worked in Turin. Here he met critic Germano Celant, who coined the term ‚ÄúArte Povera‚Äù and included him among the exponents of this new language.

In the same year he begins to insert in his works the Fibonacci mathematical logic series, 1,1,2,3,5,8, this progression according to Merz expresses the increasing intensity of psychic and physical energy that must characterize every artistic operation.

explainGeneralMuseum.m_param: Torino fu la prima citt√† italiana che promosse una raccolta pubblica di arte moderna come parte integrante del proprio Museo Civico, aperto nel 1863. Il progetto fu affidato ai giovani architetti ferraresi Carlo Bassi e Goffredo Boschetti, che realizzarono una proposta molto innovativa per il periodo.

Il 31 ottobre del 1959 venne inaugurata la nuova sede della Galleria Civica d' Arte Moderna e Contemporanea dove ancora oggi sono ospitate le raccolte. Dal 2003 la GAM fa parte della Fondazione Torino Musei e la sua collezione √® formata all'incirca di da 45.000 opere dall' Ottocento ai giorni nostri.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: Alberto Burri si √® laureato in medicina.  Durante la seconda guerra mondiale viene internato in un campo di prigionia in Texas fino al 1946. Dopo quell'esperienza inizia ad elaborare queste opere assolutamente inedite nel panorama artistico italiano ed internazionale che  rappresentano la sua visione dell'arte informale.

Mentre per alcuni critici queste opere rappresentano drammatici ricordi del secondo periodo post bellico, Burri chiarisce che le sue ricerche mirano a creare opere libere e prive di riferimenti storici o sociali. L'opera √® quindi apprezzabile come studio compositivo di materiali assemblati e di diverse superfici.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Burri si laurea in Medicina nel 1940 e inizia a dedicarsi alla pittura durante la guerra, mentre si trova prigioniero in Texas. Rientrato a Roma, nel 1946, si dedica esclusivamente alla pittura, adottando un linguaggio non figurativo ed accentuando progressivamente l'aspetto materico della sua ricerca nella serie dei Neri, dei Catrami e delle Muffe.

Nel 1951 fonda il Gruppo Origine e inizia la serie dei Sacchi, assemblaggi di sacchi di iuta ricomposti sul telaio con tagli, cuciture e scritte che  documentano la storia del loro uso precedente. Alla fine degli anni Cinquanta Burri utilizza la fiamma per tagliare, saldare e comporre le Combustioni e i Ferri di cui uno √® presente in questa sala. Burri muore a Nizza nel 1995.

explainOpera.m_param: Sia alla mia destra sia alla mia sinistra sono presenti opere dell'artista Alberto Burri, nato a citt√† di Castello in provincia di Perugia.

La scelta materica di Burri si traduce immediatamente in scelta di forma, in quanto l'artista  non rinuncia ad impaginare i sacchi di iuta sul telaio, ma interviene con tagli e suture in modo da fissare, secondo un'organizzazione spaziale precisa, l'immagine della materia consunta.

In quest'opera le trame diversificate dei differenti tipi di iuta dialogano tra loro e con i frammenti di tela dipinta, in una tassellatura di grane, forme e colori che evidenziano la volont√† di ricondurre al linguaggio della pittura i materiali di recupero.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Warhol nasce nel 1928 a Pittsburgh e nel cinquantadue si trasferisce a New York dove lavora come disegnatore pubblicitario. Nel Sessanta inizia a dipingere soggetti tratti dal paesaggio metropolitano con stesure cromatiche sempre pi√π impersonali e omogenee.

Questi soggetti, barattoli di minestra, scatole di detersivi, bottiglie di Coca-Cola, vengono rappresentate come si vedono negli scaffali dei supermercati, allineate e ripetute serialmente sulla tela.
Nel sessantatr√© abbandona la pittura per passare alla riproduzione meccanica delle immagini attraverso la serigrafia.

Accanto ai prodotti di consumo, come a porli sullo stesso livello, rappresenta i personaggi pi√π famosi del suo periodo tra cui Marilyn Monroe ed  Elvis Presley, oppure, come in questo caso, incidenti stradali o altre immagini tratte dalle prime pagine dei quotidiani. Warhol muore a New York a soli 59 anni.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: Spesso il vocabolario della Pop Art consiste nella scelta da parte degli artisti di cercare ispirazione tra le immagini di repertorio della comunicazione di massa che divengono prorompenti tra la fine degli anni '50 e l'inizio degli anni '60.

Warhol tende a sottolineare il processo di svuotamento di significato cui le icone della vita contemporanea sono destinate, portandolo agli estremi con il sistema della ripetizione.In questa opera utilizza inoltre un colore arancione che sottolinea il carattere artificiale e inautentico della rappresentazione.

Questa serigrafia rappresenta un incidente stradale in cui le vittime sono dei giovani ragazzi.La scena √® tratta da una fotografia stampata in prima pagina di un quotidiano e viene ripetuta 11 volte.

Warhol lascia uno spazio in basso a destra della serigrafia come a voler comunicare che la reiterazione potrebbe essere infinita. La ripetizione dell'immagine √® tipica della POP ART e  sottolinea il contrasto tra la drammaticit√† dell'evento, in questo caso un incidente stradale, e la perdita di significato implicita nell'iterazione seriale che lo trasforma in spettacolo.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: Che fare √® un'opera del 1968, realizzata con materiali naturali e artificiali. Il tema del riutilizzo √® un principio che governa le opere di Merz sia da un punto di vista formale, che concettuale.

Per Merz la realt√† √® soggetta ad un dinamismo costante, le cose continuano ad esistere sotto altre forme anche quando all'apparenza sono scomparse. Allo stesso modo le opere non si concludono al momento della loro realizzazione ma continuano ad esistere e a trasformarsi nel tempo.
Ecco perch√© molti materiali provengono dal mondo naturale, come in quest'opera in cui √® presente la cera che, con il calore del neon, si trasforma costantemente.

explainQuestionAuthor.m_param: Merz nasce a Milano nel 1925 ma cresce e lavora a Torino. Qui incontra il critico Germano Celant, che conia il termine ‚ÄúArte Povera‚Äù e lo include tra gli esponenti di questo nuovo linguaggio.

Partecipa fin dal sessantasette alle prime mostre del gruppo sperimentando l'accostamento di sostanze naturali, rami, foglie, pietre, cera, vetro, all'elemento artificiale del neon. Con l'adozione della forma dell'igloo, intorno al 1968, avviene l'allontanamento  definitivo dal piano bidimensionale della parete.

Nello stesso anno inizia ad inserire nelle sue opere la serie logico matematica di Fibonacci, 1,1,2,3,5,8, questa progressione esprime secondo Merz il crescere di intensit√† dell'energia psichica e fisica che deve caratterizzare ogni operazione artistica.
Dalla fine degli anni settanta recupera la figurazione realizzando grandi animali con forme arcaiche, preistorici, come li definisce l'artista.Mario Merz muore a Torino nel novembre del 2003.
Avete altre domande? Se non sapete cosa chiedere, chiedetemi la lista delle domande. Se non avete domande ditemi fine del tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: Mario Merz rientra tra i nomi di spicco del movimento artistico definito nel 1967 dal critico Germano Celant, Atre Povera. Il cinema, il teatro, le arti visive diventano per gli artisti che aderiscono a questo pensiero dei mezzi per registrare unicamente la realt√† e il presente.

Essi eliminano dalla loro ricerca tutto ci√≤ che pu√≤ sembrare riflessione e rappresentazione mimetica, per approdare ad un tipo di arte che viene appunto definita, Povera. E poveri sono anche i materiali utilizzati, anti-artistici come ad esempio gli stracci, la cartapesta, i tubi al neon ma anche materiali vegetali, animali e minerali per le loro insite caratteristiche espressive.
Avete altre domande? Se non sapete cosa chiedere, chiedetemi la lista delle domande. Se non avete domande ditemi fine del tour.

explainOpera.m_param: Siamo arrivati. Alla mia sinistra, sul pavimento, troviamo l'opera di uno dei massimi esponenti dell'arte povera: Mario Merz.
Merz cresce e lavora a Torino. A met√† degli anni sessanta inizia ad abbandonare la pittura per sperimentare l'uso di materiali diversi, come i tubi al neon, la cera, e gli oggetti d'uso quotidiano.

In quest'opera una semplice casseruola in ferro √® riempita di cera, e da questa emerge un'iscrizione composta con un tubo fluorescente al neon, che ci pone una domanda fondamentale, collegabile sia al mondo dell'arte, sia ad essere considerata in senso esistenziale. Che fare?

explainGeneralMuseum.m_param: I am happy to welcome you to this building which has two thousand years of history and which today spans four floors.

Each level allows you to see some traces of its past and the functions it performed in different eras: gateway to the city in Roman times; a medieval castle with its typical windows and battlements, as well as a magnificent garden that develops in the ancient moat ; ceilings and decorations immerse us in the atmosphere of the royal residence between the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.

Since 1934 Palazzo Madama has housed the collections of the civic museum of ancient art with a rich heritage of paintings, sculptures, goldsmiths, glass and fabrics, as well as a rich collection of ceramics exhibited here on the second floor.
This said, if you want to know more about this building, you can find more information in the museum library on the ground floor or on the website: www.palazzomadamatorino.it
If you would you like to start the tour, please say: let's start the tour. If you have more questions, please say: list of questions.

explainQuestionMainPiece.m_param: In the 10th century in China a white, hard, translucent and resonant porcelain was already being produced. This then started to change during the Yuan dinasty, in the 13th century, when, in order to mimic the jade color, green colored stonewares were created.

This new porcelain variety becomes hugely popular in Europe, under the name of ‚Äúceladon‚Äù. This name was borrowed from a character of a french novel, the pastor C√©ladon, whose dress was adorned with light green ribbons.

On the left side of the display cabinet, right on the top shelf, you can see a beautiful green colored basin. This fine piece of art has a dragon in relief at its center and veinings that imitate jade striping.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionTechnique.m_param: We know that porcelain made its appearance in China in the 10th century AD. The procedure needed to obtain a hard and translucent material is long and complex and it also requires peculiar raw materials.
The paste is made up of kaolin clay, quartz and feldspar; the surface of the object is then covered with a feldspar glaze.
The firing takes place at a high temperature, about 1400 degrees centigrade, which allows the feldspar to melt and join the underlying body, thus obtaining the wonderful beauty of porcelain.

The famous white and blue porcelain, which you can see well in this showcase, were perfected during the Ming dynasty and already in the fourteenth century similar decorations were immediately imitated in Italy in the majolica workshops of the fifteenth century.

But these were only imitations, because the secret of the composition of Chinese porcelain was discovered only in 1700 in Saxony. But I'll tell you about this when we'll arrive at the display cabinets dedicated to the Meissen manifacturing.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: From the birth of Chinese porcelain to the completion of it manifacturing process, several centuries of refinement and stylistic changes pass, which can well be observed in this showcase.

The famous Chinese, white and blue, reached its maximum expression during the Ming dynasty in the fifteenth century: it is the most exported porcelain in Europe and also includes small statuary and thin-walled pottery with relief decorations.

The use of polychrome enamels started only in the 17th century. They were applied above the deck and had prevailing colors, to the point of being able to divide the production into two large groups: the ‚Äúgreen family‚Äù and the ‚Äúpink family‚Äù. In this showcase you can see them in the lower shelves.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: In this showcase you can see the famous Chinese porcelain. White, hard and translucent porcelain originated in China about 1200 years ago during the Tang era.

The term porcelain, in the Middle Ages, was used to indicate cowries shells and it was Marco Polo, in his Million, who used porcelain to indicate the white and translucent Chinese ceramics, similar in whiteness and lightness to the aforementioned shells.

As you can see, there are not only white porcelains but also colored and different objects in shapes and sizes. Very much loved in the West since the 14th century, Chinese porcelain were massively imported into Europe starting from the 17th century. They were mainly destined to the palaces and castles of kings and aristocrats.
The transport and trade of these refined objects was managed by European shipping companies that traded with Asia, the legendary East India Companies.

explainQuestionMainPiece.m_param: On this stand you can see a she-wolf protecting her two cubs: it is part of a series of life-size animals commissioned by King Augustus the Strong and realised in 1745.

These exceptionally realistic animals, document, on the one hand, the passion for porcelain and the naturalistic interests of the sovereign on the other: in the Japanese palace in Dreasda he kept all of his porcelains, both the oriental ones and the ones from Meissen
Another palace, called Zwinger, contained a vast variety of zoomorphic finds and stuffed exotic animals, used by artists as models for their creations.
In his residence outside the city, among which Moritzburg was the most important, he kept also a lot of different enclosures with animals
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionTechnique.m_param: The secret behind porcelain, kept for centuries in China and Japan, was a two elements based compound: kaolin, an infusible clay, and the flux element, the feldspar also known as petuntse. But obtaining objects like tea cups, tea pots and small plates was quite different from realising big objects that could get damaged during the firing process.

In his notes, the author of these animals, Johann Joachim Kendler, proudly writes as follows: another great piece for the Palace. This time a life sized she-wolf, seated on its hinds legs, which lifts its head as if it was howling, in order to clearly show the fangs in its mouth.
It has two cubs sitting beneath it, one significantly bigger than the other. This has been done in order to stabilise the model while firing.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: It were two European sovereigns that, between the 16th and the 17th century, founded the expensive experimentation of new mixtures aimed to obtain porcelain so beloved due to its lightness, clear sound, and its resistance to high temperature and acidic substances.
Its composition was so unknown and mysterious that it was thought having magical properties: many thought that porcelain could reveal poison.
The firsts to discover the porcelain formula where the alchemists, hired by Augustus the Strong, in the Meissen castle, near Dresden in the modern day eastern Germany: the year was 1710!

The castle then became a proper factory, capable of producing beautiful objects which became a huge success. This lasted until the Prussian occupation of Saxony during the seven years' war, started in 1756. Fortunately the production restarted and continues to this very day.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: On this stand we can observe some masterpieces of European porcelain, born in the heart of present-day Germany thanks to experiments, trials and error.

These are large animals commissioned in 1731 by August II the Strong for his, Japanese Palace, near Dresden. We know that in just five years Johann Gottlieb Kirchner and Johann Joachim K√§ndler managed to produce 412 birds and 160 porcelain quadrupeds.

A real Noah's Ark destined to occupy the gallery on the first floor of his palace. You can see, walking around this pedestal how skilled the modelers were: they also captured the expressions and movements of these animals!

explainQuestionMainPiece.m_param: This flask has on is neck the coat of arms of the French leader Anne de Montmorency, for which it was made in 1535. The two handles are shaped like a dragon that rotates its head to bite its own body.
The marine gods with tridents and horses emerging from the waves evoke a drawing by Raphael that spread among the artists thanks to a reworking engraved by Marco Raimondi.
Mythological scenes also appear on the other known examples of the set: the flask is in fact part of a majolica service of which other examples are known in various museums around the world.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionTechnique.m_param: The majolica technique originated in the Islamic world in the Middle Ages. It consists in coating a modeled clay object, already subjected to a first firing, with an enamel based on tin oxide and lead. On this white surface the colors are spread: then the object is put in the oven and fired a second time.
The colors used in the majolica are based on metal oxides: cobalt for blue, copper for green, iron for orange or ocher, antimony for yellow, manganese for purple or brown and tin for white.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: On the bottom of the flask there are no brands or shop initials, but the style and the inscriptions on other pieces belonging to the same set and exposed in other museums indicate that it was produced in Urbino in the workshop of Guido Durantino in 1535.

The owner of the flask was the french nobelman Anne de Montmorency: he took her first name from Queen Anne of France who was her godmother. Appointed commander of all the troops of the king of France, he fought in northern Italy.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: If in China porcelain had dominated unchallenged for many centuries, in Europe especially between the 15th and 16th centuries the artists of central Italy developed painted majolica, full of colors and showing lively episodes taken from the world of myth and sacred and profane history.
This is the case of an elegant flask made in Urbino.

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: We are already here at the Italian Renaissance.

explainQuestionMainPiece.m_param: This tureen is one of Carlo Antonio Grue's masterpieces. Grue was considered one of the most important majolica painters of the eighteenth century: his style is famous for the golden touches, applied with a third firing, which he used to highlight figures and landscapes.
The fund has no brand: on the other hand, the Grue's shop did not mark its products; the painters signatures can rarely be found.

You can admire the richness of the ornamentation and the symmetrical arrangement of the decorative elements. In terms of colors, yellow and green dominate. The snakes' tails are knotted to close the handles.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionTechnique.m_param: Looking at the soup tureen here in the center, one understands the distinctive features of the production from Abruzzo. The lid is decorated with winged cherubs seated or standing on a ledge, some of them are holding a wreath of laurel leaves.

The golden touches were applied to the already colored and fired object, which was then glazed a third time at lower temperatures. The technique of decorating majolica with gold was already in use in Castelli in the sixteenth century.

The village of Castelli, perched on a mountain at the foot of the Gran Sasso, has been one of the main Italian, ceramic villages, since the Renaissance. In this display cabinet you cann admire various examples produced in its formidable workshops.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: In the third decades of the seventeenth century the majolica of Castelli d'Abruzzo went through a period of renewal thanks to the work of Francesco Grue who was born in 1618.

Francesco Grue was the author of the first baroque decorations depicting historical figures. He preferred the representation of mythological scenes, episodes coming from ancient history, biblical stories or, more simply, hunting scenes taken from printed models.

The most authoritative representative of this new artistic direction was his son Carlo Antonio Grue who brought the castellana majolica to the highest artistic expression, helping to spread the motifs derived from the engravings and developing a personal formal code and extremely refined. The adopted pictorial style is often accentuated by a very fine fabric of gold highlights, to give relief to the forms.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: As you can see, this cabinet contains richly refined ceramics decorated with historical figures. This is the main feature of the Castelli ceramics from the 17th century.

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: In the next showcase there are richly decorated ceramics. It is the characteristic of Castelli ceramics from the 1600s.

explainQuestionMainPiece.m_param: In front of you, on the central shelf, you can admire a part of the ‚ÄúTea and chocolate set‚Äù that the king Augustus the Strong sent as a gift to Vittorio Amedeo II, king of Sardinia. If you look closely, you can see that the pieces bear the coat of arms of Vittorio Amedeo II (the saucers) or his figures (the cups), and are marked with the letters, AR, initials of the generous German king (Augustus Rex).

The painted surface shows people talking, looking after children, playing instruments, preparing and serving hot drinks. Dogs, birds and squirrels can also be seen. A distant, fairytale-like atmosphere shows us the profound fascination the East exerted on eighteenth-century Europe.

The exotic nature of the scenes painted on the different cups reflects the exitoc nature of the hot drinks the porcelain was meant for: the tea coming from China, and the chocolate coming from the West Indies, that is, the new american world.

These were luxury items, that only the upper class could afford: chocolate, in particular, became the beverage of the european arisocracy, for its nutritional characteristics and meant to be served in the morning, during breakfast. Usually, tea wes served in shallow cups, as for coffee. Chocolate, instead, was served in taller cups, or even in a small dish in which liquid could be poured to cool it down.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionTechnique.m_param: In 1725 the porcelain form Meissen is characterized by colors, slow fire, with a new color palette until then unknown. New models and inspirations are also introduced, mostly of eastern inspiration, and starting from the appreciation of chinoiseries that was a characteristic of Meissen.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: After creating, around 1710, the first porecelain factory in Europe, king Augustus the second, elector of Saxony and king of Poland, started to send porcelain from Meissen as diplomatic gifts to European sovereigns, among which was Vittorio Amedeo the second, king of Sardinia, in Setpember of 1725.

The 12 boxes from Dresda arrived in Turin in November of 1725: among the 300 pieces were both porcelains created for the occasion, and pieces from Augustus personal collection, that was for show in the japanese palace od Dresda.
This was the first time that porcelains from Meissen of royal provenance were sent to a foreing ruler. For the gift, Vittorio Amedeo sent some fine tapestries in return.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: Here you can see the porcelain that made the Meissen factory famous. Augustus the second the Strong had started the first European porcelain manufacture in Meissen, thanks to the discovery of the secret of porcelain made by his alchemists.

A great contribution to the success of this ceramic was given by the painter Johann Gregor Huroldt, who arrived in Meissen in 1720 and who combined floral and landscape decoration with oriental scenes, all characterized by a wealth of colors, until then unseen in the decoration of porcelain.

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: The next showcase is dedicated to a factory in Meissen, near Dresden, in what is now Germany.

explainQuestionMainPiece.m_param: I want to show you the clock holder on the middle shelf. An inscription on its back says it was made in 1725. The text in italian language says: ANNO A NATO, SLAVATORE 1725.

The clock shows elements from chinese culture, such as the pagoda, the guardian lions, the dragons, and elements of baroque, such as putti, the frames, and large leaves curved at the top. This artefact is a rare example of the sophisticated production coming from the factory Du Paquer in Vienna.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionTechnique.m_param: The history of porcelain in Europe is a story of experiments that are not always successful to make kaolin hard and resistant. From Meissen the manufacturing of porcelain spread to elegant Vienna.

A distinctive sign of this manufacture is found in the handles, that are shaped like animals: dragons, salamanders and fish or small human-like figures. Equally characteristic are the bright painted decorations with a color palette dominated by rich purples and pinks, iron reds, blues, yellows and different shades of green.

What you see in this showcase and in the one next to it is an extremely original porcelain manufacture that experiments with new combinations, always maintaining a very high level of quality: despite the great economic difficulties.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: The Du paquier of Vienna was the second in Europe after that of Meissen to undertake the production of hard ceramics, the real, porcelain.

Founded in 1718 thanks to the entrepreneurial skills of a court officer, Claudius Innocentius du Paquier, in a few years was able to churn out a great variety of shapes for the table sets of the European courts.

In 1744, bent by debts, the factory closed: under the reign of Maria Theresa of Austria , the factory was nationalized and incorporated into the imperial heritage, becoming the Imperial Porcelain Manufactory of Vienna.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: We are now in Vienna where, in 1718, Claudius Innocentius du Paquier founded the second production in Europe able to manufacture porcelain, .Following the example of the one in Meissen.

In this showcase you can see lampshades, candelabra, clock boxes and inkwell trays, showing that the inventive of this factory was able to adapt porcelain to different everyday objects, and not only for table porcelain.

explainQuestionMainPiece.m_param: This beautiful white porcelain sculpture is a dancing Faun, it is 126 cm high and, as you can see, it is a work of exceptional technical and artistic quality. The Faun is recognizable by his pointy ears and small horns on its head, and is dancing.

We have to imagine a fast paced music, to which the Faun adds two percussion instruments: he holds cymbals on his hands, two bronze plates clashing together; on the right foot he wears a special sandal, to keep the tempo with two small disks applied to the soles.
The head and torso are bent forward and this makes the dance very realistic.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionTechnique.m_param: The statue is referencing a bronze created by Massimiliano Soldani Benzi in the end of the 1600s, which was derived from a marble roman replica of a greek opera from the fourth century B.C.  It is now located in the Gallerie degli Uffizi.
This Faun has been made throughout different epochs and with different materials: marble, bronze and porcelain. But it's beauty has been the same!
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: The manufacture in Doccia was born in 1737 on the wish of Marques Carlo Ginori, that established inside Villa Buondelmonti, near Sesto Fiorentino, one of the first large porcelain factores.
The dancing faun is dated to this first period when, under the guidance of Gaspero Bruschi, the repertoire was extented to operas from the Tuscant of 1500 and roman and greek originals.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: The dancing faun in front of us was made in 1749 in Manifattura Ginori di Doccia, near Firenze. The young inhabitat of the woods is dancing energetically, is smiling and the body moves to the rythm of music.

This spectacular sculpture comes from the collection Emanuele Tapparelli d'Azeglio, and is one of a rich collection of statues that were made in the second half of the 1700s Manifattura di Doccia, in a one to one scale, on the example of greek and roman sculptures that were found in the Gallerie degli Uffizi.
It is an example of the experimentation of using porcelain not only for cutlery and small objects, but for large sculptures.

explainQuestionMainPiece.m_param: This set grew to more that 600 pieces, and 57 are conserved in Palazzo Madama, among bottom plates and flat dishes, oval and circular plates, soup bowls, bowls for legumes, salads, for butter and mustard, glass and bottle chillers, salt shakers, cups, trays and saucers.

Here you can admire a small selection and imagine how a laid table would look. Besides the richness of shapes, imagine the surprise and amusement of the guests seeing all these animals. Almost like a virtual zoological garden.

explainQuestionTechnique.m_param: Aside from the small round tureen in earthenware, all the pieces are made of porcelain: some in a soft paste with an hard glass paint applied, drawing with toned-down colors. Others, in hard paste from the Poulard-Prad factory, white and string, painted in stronger colors.
The quality of the pieces made in the Real Fabbrica is attributed to Giacomo Milani, first painter in the factory, already author of the famous Servizio delle Vedute del Regno, and his collaborators.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to finish the tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: Part of the set was made between the year 1800 and 1806 in Naples, in the Real Fabbrica della Porcellana: after the french invasion of 1807 the factory was closed and bought by a society that acquired vases, models and tools and moved production to the convent of Santa Maria della Vita.

More that 100 pieces of the set with a lilac stripe were took from the warehouse and destined to the new ruler Giuseppe Bonaparte in Palazzo Reale di Caserta. In the following years, the original nucleus was integrated in multiple takes.
From Caserta, after the return of the Borbone family in 1815, the set, that was composed of 640 pieces, was moved to the Reggia di Portici, the original destination.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to finish the tour.

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: Lets's take a slighly longer trip. As we head to the next display, on your left hand you can see porcelains made in Vinovo, a small city near Turin, between the 18th and 19th century. During this period you can observe the neoclassical fashion, simple and linear, that characterized both the decoration of the tea and coffee sets, as well as small statues.

On the side of the display you can see an unusual exhibition of tea pots. Each one of them has a structure where a tealight can be inserted to keep warm the beverage. Your choice of preference can be anything between exotic animals, strange characters, elegant ladies, frightening monsters or small houses.

explainGeneralMuseum.m_param: Sono felice di accoglierti in questo palazzo che ha duemila anni di storia e che si sviluppa oggi su quattro piani.

Ogni livello ti permette di scorgere alcune tracce del suo passato e delle funzioni che l'edificio ha svolto nelle diverse epoche: √® stato porta di accesso alla citt√† in et√† romana; castello medievale con finestre e merlature, oltre a un magnifico giardino che si sviluppa nell'antico fossato; soffitti e decorazioni ci immergono nelle atmosfere della residenza regia tra Sei e Settecento.

Dal 1934 Palazzo Madama ospita le collezioni del museo civico d'arte antica con un ricco patrimonio di dipinti, sculture, oreficerie, vetri e tessuti, oltre a una ricca collezione di ceramiche esposta qui al secondo piano.
Ecco, ti ho raccontato velocemente dove sei, ma puoi trovare pi√π informazioni nella libreria del museo al piano terra oppure sul sito web palazzomadamatorino.it

explainQuestionMainPiece.m_param: Gi√† nel X secolo in Cina si produce una porcellana bianca, dura traslucida e sonora, ma i primi cambiamenti avvengono durante la dinastia Yuan, nel XIII secolo, quando si creano gres di colore verde, per imitare il colore della giada: diventa una apprezzatissima porcellana che in Europa prende il nome di ‚Äúceladon‚Äù prendendo il nome dal personaggio di un romanzo francese, il pastore C√©ladon, il cui abito era ornato di nastri di colore verde chiaro.

Nel ripiano pi√π in alto a sinistra della vetrina puoi vedere un bellissimo bacile tutto verde, decorato al centro dalla figura di un grande drago a rilievo e caratterizzato da venature a imitare le striature della giada.
Avete altre domande? Se non sapete cosa chiedere, chiedetemi la lista delle domande. Se non avete domande ditemi continua il tour.

explainQuestionTechnique.m_param: Sappiamo che la porcellana fece la sua comparsa in Cina nel X secolo dopo Cristo. Il procedimento che permette di ottenere un materiale duro e traslucido √® lungo e complesso e si basa anche sull'uso di materie prime particolari.
La pasta √® composta da argilla caol√¨nica, quarzo e feldspato; la superficie dell'oggetto √® poi ricoperta da una vetrina di feldspato.

La cottura a temperatura di circa 1400 gradi centigradi permette al feldspato di sciogliersi e di unirsi al corpo sottostante, ottenendo cos√¨ il prodigio della bellezza della porcellana. Le famose porcellane bianche e blu, che vedi in questa vetrina, si perfezionarono durante la dinastia Ming e gi√† nel Quattrocento, decori simili furono adottati in Italia nelle botteghe di maiolica.

Ma si trattava solo di imitazioni, perch√© il segreto della composizione della porcellana cinese fu individuato solo nel 1700 in Sassonia. Ma di questa storia parleremo nelle prossime vetrine dedicate alla manifattura di Meissen, se vorrai continuare il giro con me.
Avete altre domande? Se non sapete cosa chiedere, chiedetemi la lista delle domande. Se non avete domande ditemi continua il tour.

explainQuestionEpoch.m_param: Dalla nascita allo sviluppo della porcellana cinese passano diversi secoli di perfezionamento e cambiamenti stilistici che ben si possono osservare in questa vetrina.

Il celebre ‚Äúbianco e blu‚Äù cinese raggiunge invece la sua massima espressione nel XV secolo, durante la dinastia Ming: √® la porcellana pi√π esportata in Europa e comprende anche piccola statuaria e vasellame caratterizzato da pareti sottili e decori a rilievo.

Solo nel Seicento, si arriva agli smalti policromi che vengono applicati sopra coperta e sono caratterizzati da alcuni colori prevalenti, al punto da poter suddividere la produzione in due grandi nuclei: la ‚Äúfamiglia verde‚Äù e la ‚Äúfamiglia rosa, che vedi qui in basso nella vetrina.
Avete altre domande? Se non sapete cosa chiedere, chiedetemi la lista delle domande. Se non avete domande ditemi continua il tour.

explainOpera.m_param: In questa vetrina sono conservate alcune ceramiche cinesi. La porcellana bianca, dura e traslucida √® nata in Cina circa 1200 anni fa durante l'epoca Tang.

Nel Medioevo erano chiamate ‚Äúporcellane‚Äù le conchiglie cipree ed √® stato Marco Polo, nel suo ‚ÄúMilione‚Äù, a chiamare cos√¨ le bianchissime e traslucide ceramiche orientali, simili alle conchiglie per candore e leggerezza.

warningNextNavigation.m_param: Our tour ends here, thanks for being with me in this short tour. Feel free to ask our researchers any question you might have. They will be happy to explain their work. I will now return to my charging point. Please make some space.

explainQuestionHowItWorks.m_param: Highly trained technicians assemble, calibrate and test the robots before shipping them all over the world.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: The Icubb robot is a platform largely used to do research, not only in the italian institute of technology, but also in other laboratories in the world. This room is the production area. Here we assemble the robots and perform the final calibration and testing before they are shipped to the final users. Here we also perform maintenance and repair robots that break during experiments.
argueBoth

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: We are now in the Center for Robotics and Intelligent Systems. Here we build humanoid robots like the Icubb and me. Researchers and engineers here, work to advance our capability of interacting with the environment and others. Learning to perceive the environment, manipulate objects and locomotion.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: One of the unique features of the Icubb is the system of tactile sensors, a sort of artificial skin. The black fabric that covers the robot is the external layer of a system of sensors that measure the pressure. In other words, Icubb knows when it is touched, and can react appropriately. Overall, there are 4500 sensors mounted on the arms and torso.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionHowItWorks.m_param: The robot is equipped with a set of embedded processors that read the information from the sensors such as the skin, the force sensors and the cameras. These embedded processors also control the motors to reach a certain position. The computer on the head that act as a hub, it broadcasts sensory information to the robot network and receives commands to control the robot. The external cluster performs the majority of the computation using the sensory feedback, it controls the robot by sending commands to the hub on the head.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionFuturePlans.m_param: We are currently studying how to perceive and manipulate objects using a combination of vision, touch and machine learning. We are especially interested in how machine learning models can be expanded online by letting the robot interact with the environment.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: This robot is the first Icubb prototype that was built. Although it has been largely modified and upgraded along the years some components are still original. With this robot we study object manipulation, visual and tactile perception.
pointToLeftBothArms
idleMove
Do you have any questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.
startHearing

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: The next robot will be the black Icubb.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: In this area researchers study bio-inspired algorithms that take advantage of the high temporal resolution and bandwidth saving of event driven sensors, such as Spiking Neural Networks.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionHowItWorks.m_param: Conventional sensors provide information at a constant, given, frame rate. Event driven sensors, on the other hand, provide information only when changes are detected. These type of sensors, therefore, provide information at high temporal resolution while saving bandwidth.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionFuturePlans.m_param: The robot is equipped with two frame-based cameras and two event-driven cameras. This allow studying if and how to integrate and take advantage of the two type of sensors.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainOpera.m_param: This iCub is special. Along with a standard vision system, it is equipped with event-driven cameras.

sayWhileNavigating.m_param: Let's quickly move here, to see two more robots.

explainQuestionMoreDetails.m_param: The head has been simplified reducing the number of motors. It now has only two degrees of freedom for movement, and a screen that allows to draw and animate pictures that simulate the face. The hands have only two motors, but allow it to interact with the environment and pick up objects. The wheels allow the robot to navigate in the environment with ease.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionHowItWorks.m_param: The robot has three computers on board and a set of embedded processors similar to those on the Icubb. The head has two RGB cameras and a realsense camera for depth perception. The lidar at the base is used to detect obstacles and allow to robot to localize itself in the environment. The amrs and hands are also equiped with a tactile system similar to the one of the Icubb.
Do you have any other questions? If you don't know what to ask, ask me for the list of questions. If you don't have questions, ask me to continue the tour.

explainQuestionFuturePlans.m_param: The robot today can navigate autonomously and interact with humans with a speech interface. Using its sensors the robot can detect and avoid obstacles, recognize and grasp objects.

explainOpera.m_param: R1 has been designed based on the know-how and the technology developed on the Icubb. It is a simpler system, meant to reduce the overall cost, but also to support the study of applications in the context of assistive robotics.
